citation.article-title: Marinococcus gen. nov., a new genus for motile cocci with meso-diaminopimelic acid in the cell wall; and Marinococcus albus sp. nov. and Marinococcus halophilus (Novitsky and Kushner) comb. nov.
citation.source: The Journal of General and Applied Microbiology

p.s: Description of Marinococcus albus sp. nov.
Marinococcus albus (al'bus. L. adj. albus white)
Cells are spherical, 1.0 to 1.2 μm in diameter, occurring singly, in pairs, and in clumps.
The motile cells usually have one or two flagella.
Colonies on nutrient agar plate with 5 to 20% of sodium chloride are round, smooth, opaque, and nonpigmented.
The following tests are positive: Benzidine test for porphyrine, oxidase, nitrate reduction, urease, and extracellular DNase.

The following tests are negative: Production of acid from glucose and other sugars, hydrolysis of gelatin, casein, starch, esculin, and Tween 80, production of acetoin, production of hydrogen sulfide, production of indole, arginine dihydrolase, lysine and ornithine decarboxylases, phenylalanine deaminase, phosphatase, eggyolk reaction, hemolysis, and growth on nutrient agar without salt, and growth on Simmons citrate agar.
Optimum salinity from 5 to 1500 sodium chloride.
The cell wall contains peptidoglycan of meso-diaminopimelic acid type.
